snippet: Excluding a drug that’s no better, and twice as expensive, isn’t rationing — it’s rational.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Peter B Bach, Leonard B Saltz and Robert E Wittes, doctors at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, explains the hospital's decision not to use new cancer drug Zaltrap, which has proved to be no more effective but is more than twice as expensive; contends that this is one example of how the medical community needs to consider financial costs of treatments for patients alongside their benefits.

byline.original: By PETER B. BACH, LEONARD B. SALTZ and ROBERT E. WITTES

lead_paragraph: Excluding a drug that’s no better, and twice as expensive, isn’t rationing — it’s rational.

headline.seo: A Hospital Says ‘No’ to an $11,000-a-Month Cancer Drug
